CWE-327 Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptog.name: CWE-327 Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
CWE-327 Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptog.description: The use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm is an unnecessary risk that may result in the exposure of sensitive information.

CWE-327.name: CWE-327
CWE-327.description: The use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm is an unnecessary risk that may result in the exposure of sensitive information.

FF1049.name: FF1049
FF1049.description: The crypt functions use a poor one-way hashing algorithm; since they only accept passwords of 8 characters or fewer and only a two-byte salt, they are excessively vulnerable to dictionary attacks given today's faster computing equipment

FF1048.name: FF1048
FF1048.description: This function is not sufficiently random for security-related functions such as key and nonce creation

FF1050.name: FF1050
FF1050.description: DES only supports a 56-bit keysize, which is too small given today's computers

FF1051.name: FF1051
FF1051.description: These keysizes are too small given today's computers

CWE-362 race_conditions.name: CWE-362 race_conditions
CWE-362 race_conditions.description: The program contains a code sequence that can run concurrently with other code, and the code sequence requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence that is operating concurrently.

FF1030.name: FF1030
FF1030.description: This usually indicates a security flaw.  If an attacker can change anything along the path between the call to access() and the file's actual use (e.g., by moving files), the attacker can exploit the race condition

CWE-362.name: CWE-362
CWE-362.description: The program contains a code sequence that can run concurrently with other code, and the code sequence requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence that is operating concurrently.

FF1034.name: FF1034
FF1034.description: On some old systems, vfork() permits race conditions, and it's very difficult to use correctly

FF1031.name: FF1031
FF1031.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1032.name: FF1032
FF1032.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1033.name: FF1033
FF1033.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1040.name: FF1040
FF1040.description: Check when opening files - can an attacker redirect it (via symlinks), force the opening of special file type (e.g., device files), move things around to create a race condition, control its ancestors, or change its contents?

FF1035.name: FF1035
FF1035.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results. Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL.

CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management.name: CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management
CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management.description: The software does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

FF1052.name: FF1052
FF1052.description: chroot can be very helpful, but is hard to use correctly

CWE-250.name: CWE-250
CWE-250.description: The software performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

FF1056.name: FF1056
FF1056.description: If this call fails, the program could fail to drop heightened privileges

CWE-829 Inclusion_of_functionality_from_.name: CWE-829 Inclusion_of_functionality_from_untrusted_control_sphere
CWE-829 Inclusion_of_functionality_from_.description: The software imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

FF1058.name: FF1058
FF1058.description: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used

FF1059.name: FF1059
FF1059.description: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used

CWE-190 Integer_wraparound.name: CWE-190 Integer_wraparound
CWE-190 Integer_wraparound.description: The software performs a calculation that can produce an integer overflow or wraparound, when the logic assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than the original value. This can introduce other weaknesses when the calculation is used for resource management or execution control.

CWE-190.name: CWE-190
CWE-190.description: The software performs a calculation that can produce an integer overflow or wraparound, when the logic assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than the original value. This can introduce other weaknesses when the calculation is used for resource management or execution control.

FF1047.name: FF1047
FF1047.description: Unless checked, the resulting number can exceed the expected range

CWE-77 OS_command_injection.name: CWE-77 OS_command_injection
CWE-77 OS_command_injection.description: The software constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.

CWE-78.name: CWE-78
CWE-78.description: The software constructs all or part of an OS command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended OS command when it is sent to a downstream component.

FF1045.name: FF1045
FF1045.description: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1046.name: FF1046
FF1046.description: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1043.name: FF1043
FF1043.description: This causes a new program to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1044.name: FF1044
FF1044.description: This causes a new program to execute and is difficult to use safely

CWE-1177 Use_of_prohibited_code.name: CWE-1177 Use_of_prohibited_code
CWE-1177 Use_of_prohibited_code.description: The software uses a function, library, or third party component that has been explicitly prohibited, whether by the developer or the customer.

CWE-676.name: CWE-676
CWE-676.description: The program invokes a potentially dangerous function that could introduce a vulnerability if it is used incorrectly, but the function can also be used safely.

FF1069.name: FF1069
FF1069.description: This C routine is considered obsolete (as opposed to the shell command by the same name).   The interaction of this function with SIGALRM and other timer functions such as sleep(), alarm(), setitimer(), and nanosleep() is unspecified

FF1066.name: FF1066
FF1066.description: These functions are considered obsolete on most systems, and very non-portable (Linux-based systems handle them radically different, basically if gsignal/ssignal were the same as raise/signal respectively, while System V considers them a separate set and obsolete)

CWE-807 Reliance_on_untrusted_inputs.name: CWE-807 Reliance_on_untrusted_inputs
CWE-807 Reliance_on_untrusted_inputs.description: The application uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of an input, but the input can be modified by an untrusted actor in a way that bypasses the protection mechanism.

FF1053.name: FF1053
FF1053.description: Environment variables are untrustable input if they can be set by an attacker.  They can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

FF1054.name: FF1054
FF1054.description: This function is synonymous with 'getenv(\"HOME\")';it returns untrustable input if the environment can be set by an attacker.  It can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

FF1055.name: FF1055
FF1055.description: This function is synonymous with 'getenv(\"TMP\")';it returns untrustable input if the environment can be set by an attacker. It can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

CWE-807.name: CWE-807
CWE-807.description: The application uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of an input, but the input can be modified by an untrusted actor in a way that bypasses the protection mechanism.

FF1062.name: FF1062
FF1062.description: It's often easy to fool getlogin.  Sometimes it does not work at all, because some program messed up the utmp file.  Often, it gives only the first 8 characters of the login name. The user currently logged in on the controlling tty of our program need not be the user who started it.  Avoid getlogin() for security-related purposes

CWE-119 Improper_restriction_of_operatio.name: CWE-119 Improper_restriction_of_operations_in_memory
CWE-119 Improper_restriction_of_operatio.description: The software performs operations on a memory buffer, but it can read from or write to a memory location that is outside of the intended boundary of the buffer.

CWE-126.name: CWE-126
CWE-126.description: The software reads from a buffer using buffer access mechanisms such as indexes or pointers that reference memory locations after the targeted buffer.

FF1022.name: FF1022
FF1022.description: Does not handle strings that are not \\0-terminated; if given one it may perform an over-read (it could cause a crash if unprotected)

FF1071.name: FF1071
FF1071.description: Function does not check the second iterator for over-read conditions

FF1065.name: FF1065
FF1065.description: This function is obsolete and not portable. It was in SUSv2 but removed by POSIX.2.  What it does exactly varies considerably between systems, particularly in where its prompt is displayed and where it gets its data (e.g., /dev/tty, stdin, stderr, etc.). In addition, some implementations overflow buffers.

FF1027.name: FF1027
FF1027.description: Some older implementations do not protect against internal buffer overflows

FF1028.name: FF1028
FF1028.description: This does not protect against buffer overflows by itself, so use with caution

FF1029.name: FF1029
FF1029.description: Check buffer boundaries if used in a loop including recursive loops

FF1014.name: FF1014
FF1014.description: Does not check for buffer overflows

FF1020.name: FF1020
FF1020.description: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows

FF1021.name: FF1021
FF1021.description: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows

FF1013.name: FF1013
FF1013.description: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues

CWE-120.name: CWE-120
CWE-120.description: The program copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer, leading to a buffer overflow.

FF1005.name: FF1005
FF1005.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when concatenating to destination [MS-banned]

FF1006.name: FF1006
FF1006.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when concatenating to destination [MS-banned]

FF1007.name: FF1007
FF1007.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when concatenating to destination [MS-banned]

FF1008.name: FF1008
FF1008.description: Easily used incorrectly; doesn't always \\0-terminate or check for invalid pointers [MS-banned]

FF1001.name: FF1001
FF1001.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned]

FF1012.name: FF1012
FF1012.description: Subject to buffer overflow if buffer is not as big as claimed

FF1023.name: FF1023
FF1023.description: Requires maximum length in CHARACTERS, not bytes

FF1002.name: FF1002
FF1002.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned]

FF1024.name: FF1024
FF1024.description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows

FF1003.name: FF1003
FF1003.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned]

FF1025.name: FF1025
FF1025.description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows

FF1004.name: FF1004
FF1004.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination

FF1009.name: FF1009
FF1009.description: Easily used incorrectly; doesn't always \\0-terminate or check for invalid pointers [MS-banned]

FF1064.name: FF1064
FF1064.description: This function is dangerous; it may overflow the provided buffer. It extracts data from a 'protected' area, but most systems have many commands to let users modify the protected area, and it's not always clear what their limits are.  Best to avoid using this function altogether

FF1010.name: FF1010
FF1010.description: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned]

FF1011.name: FF1011
FF1011.description: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned]

FF1026.name: FF1026
FF1026.description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows, and some implementations can overflow internally

CWE-668 Exposure_of_resource_to_wrong_sp.name: CWE-668 Exposure_of_resource_to_wrong_sphere
CWE-668 Exposure_of_resource_to_wrong_sp.description: The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

CWE-732.name: CWE-732
CWE-732.description: The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors.

FF1041.name: FF1041
FF1041.description: Ensure that umask is given most restrictive possible setting (e.g., 066 or 077)

FF1042.name: FF1042
FF1042.description: Temporary file race condition in certain cases (e.g., if run as SYSTEM in many versions of Windows)

FF1060.name: FF1060
FF1060.description: Never create NULL ACLs; an attacker can set it to Everyone (Deny All Access), which would even forbid administrator access

FF1061.name: FF1061
FF1061.description: This doesn't set the inheritance bits in the access control entry (ACE) header

CWE-134.name: CWE-134
CWE-134.description: The software uses a function that accepts a format string as an argument, but the format string originates from an external source.

FF1016.name: FF1016
FF1016.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1017.name: FF1017
FF1017.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1018.name: FF1018
FF1018.description: If syslog's format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1019.name: FF1019
FF1019.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited, and note that sprintf variations do not always 0-terminate

CWE-377.name: CWE-377
CWE-377.description: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

FF1039.name: FF1039
FF1039.description: Potential for temporary file vulnerability in some circumstances.  Some older Unix-like systems create temp files with permission to write by all by default, so be sure to set the umask to override this. Also, some older Unix systems might fail to use O_EXCL when opening the file, so make sure that O_EXCL is used by the library

FF1036.name: FF1036
FF1036.description: Function tmpfile() has a security flaw on some systems (e.g., older System V systems)

Authenticity.name: Authenticity
Authenticity.description: The property that data originated from its purported source.

CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management.name: CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management
CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management.description: The software does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

FF1052.name: FF1052
FF1052.description: chroot can be very helpful, but is hard to use correctly

CWE-250.name: CWE-250
CWE-250.description: The software performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

FF1056.name: FF1056
FF1056.description: If this call fails, the program could fail to drop heightened privileges

Also, some older Unix systems might fail to use O_EXCL when opening the file, so make sure that O_EXCL is used by the library

FF1036.name: FF1036
FF1036.description: Function tmpfile() has a security flaw on some systems (e.g., older System V systems)

CWE-710 Improper_adherence_to_coding_sta.name: CWE-710 Improper_adherence_to_coding_standards
CWE-710 Improper_adherence_to_coding_sta.description: The software does not follow certain coding rules for development, which can lead to weaknesses.

CWE-1177 Use_of_prohibited_code.description: The software uses a function, library, or third party component that has been explicitly prohibited, whether by the developer or the customer.

CWE-676.description: The program invokes a potentially dangerous function that could introduce a vulnerability if it is used incorrectly, but the function can also be used safely.

CWE-691 Insufficient_control_flow_manage.name: CWE-691 Insufficient_control_flow_management
CWE-691 Insufficient_control_flow_manage.description: The code does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating conditions in which the control flow can be modified in unexpected ways.

CWE-362 race_conditions.description: The program contains a code sequence that can run concurrently with other code, and the code sequence requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence that is operating concurrently.

Confidentiality.name: Confidentiality
Confidentiality.description: Preserving authorized restrictions on information access and disclosure, including means for protecting personal privacy and proprietary information.

Cross_cutting.name: Cross_cutting
Cross_cutting.description: Weaknesses in this category are related to the design and architecture of multiple security tactics and how they affect a system. A weakness in this category could lead to a degradation in the quality of many capabilities.

Limit_exposure.name: Limit_exposure
Limit_exposure.description: Weaknesses in this category are related to the design and architecture of the entry points to a system. Frequently these deal with minimizing the attack surface through designing the system with the least needed amount of entry points.

Integrity.name: Integrity

FF1064.name: FF1064
FF1064.description: This function is dangerous; it may overflow the provided buffer. It extracts data from a 'protected' area, but most systems have many commands to let users modify the protected area, and it's not always clear what their limits are.  Best to avoid using this function altogether

FF1010.name: FF1010
FF1010.description: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned]

FF1011.name: FF1011
FF1011.description: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned]

FF1026.name: FF1026
FF1026.description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows, and some implementations can overflow internally

Vendor Security Quality.name: Vendor Security Quality
Vendor Security Quality.description: The total security quality value representing the entire system

Authenticity.name: Authenticity
Authenticity.description: The property that data originated from its purported source.

CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management.name: CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management
CWE-269 Improper_privilege_management.description: The software does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

FF1052.name: FF1052
FF1052.description: chroot can be very helpful, but is hard to use correctly

CWE-250.name: CWE-250
CWE-250.description: The software performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

FF1056.name: FF1056
FF1056.description: If this call fails, the program could fail to drop heightened privileges

CWE-668 Exposure_of_resource_to_wrong_sp.name: CWE-668 Exposure_of_resource_to_wrong_sphere
CWE-668 Exposure_of_resource_to_wrong_sp.description: The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

CWE-732.name: CWE-732
CWE-732.description: The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors.

FF1041.name: FF1041
FF1041.description: Ensure that umask is given most restrictive possible setting (e.g., 066 or 077)

FF1042.name: FF1042
FF1042.description: Temporary file race condition in certain cases (e.g., if run as SYSTEM in many versions of Windows)

FF1060.name: FF1060
FF1060.description: Never create NULL ACLs; an attacker can set it to Everyone (Deny All Access), which would even forbid administrator access

FF1061.name: FF1061
FF1061.description: This doesn't set the inheritance bits in the access control entry (ACE) header

CWE-134.name: CWE-134
CWE-134.description: The software uses a function that accepts a format string as an argument, but the format string originates from an external source.

FF1016.name: FF1016
FF1016.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1017.name: FF1017
FF1017.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1018.name: FF1018
FF1018.description: If syslog's format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1019.name: FF1019
FF1019.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited, and note that sprintf variations do not always 0-terminate

CWE-377.name: CWE-377
CWE-377.description: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

FF1039.name: FF1039
FF1039.description: Potential for temporary file vulnerability in some circumstances.  Some older Unix-like systems create temp files with permission to write by all by default, so be sure to set the umask to override this. Also, some older Unix systems might fail to use O_EXCL when opening the file, so make sure that O_EXCL is used by the library

FF1036.name: FF1036
FF1036.description: Function tmpfile() has a security flaw on some systems (e.g., older System V systems)

CWE-710 Improper_adherence_to_coding_sta.name: CWE-710 Improper_adherence_to_coding_standards
CWE-710 Improper_adherence_to_coding_sta.description: The software does not follow certain coding rules for development, which can lead to weaknesses.

CWE-1177 Use_of_prohibited_code.name: CWE-1177 Use_of_prohibited_code
CWE-1177 Use_of_prohibited_code.description: The software uses a function, library, or third party component that has been explicitly prohibited, whether by the developer or the customer.

CWE-676.name: CWE-676
CWE-676.description: The program invokes a potentially dangerous function that could introduce a vulnerability if it is used incorrectly, but the function can also be used safely.

FF1069.name: FF1069
FF1069.description: This C routine is considered obsolete (as opposed to the shell command by the same name).   The interaction of this function with SIGALRM and other timer functions such as sleep(), alarm(), setitimer(), and nanosleep() is unspecified

FF1066.name: FF1066
FF1066.description: These functions are considered obsolete on most systems, and very non-portable (Linux-based systems handle them radically different, basically if gsignal/ssignal were the same as raise/signal respectively, while System V considers them a separate set and obsolete)

CWE-691 Insufficient_control_flow_manage.name: CWE-691 Insufficient_control_flow_management
CWE-691 Insufficient_control_flow_manage.description: The code does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating conditions in which the control flow can be modified in unexpected ways.

CWE-362 race_conditions.name: CWE-362 race_conditions
CWE-362 race_conditions.description: The program contains a code sequence that can run concurrently with other code, and the code sequence requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence that is operating concurrently.

FF1030.name: FF1030
FF1030.description: This usually indicates a security flaw.  If an attacker can change anything along the path between the call to access() and the file's actual use (e.g., by moving files), the attacker can exploit the race condition

CWE-362.name: CWE-362
CWE-362.description: The program contains a code sequence that can run concurrently with other code, and the code sequence requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence that is operating concurrently.

FF1034.name: FF1034
FF1034.description: On some old systems, vfork() permits race conditions, and it's very difficult to use correctly

FF1031.name: FF1031
FF1031.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1032.name: FF1032
FF1032.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1033.name: FF1033
FF1033.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1040.name: FF1040
FF1040.description: Check when opening files - can an attacker redirect it (via symlinks), force the opening of special file type (e.g., device files), move things around to create a race condition, control its ancestors, or change its contents?

FF1035.name: FF1035
FF1035.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results. Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL.

Confidentiality.name: Confidentiality
Confidentiality.description: Preserving authorized restrictions on information access and disclosure, including means for protecting personal privacy and proprietary information.

CWE-327 Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptog.name: CWE-327 Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
CWE-327 Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptog.description: The use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm is an unnecessary risk that may result in the exposure of sensitive information.

CWE-327.name: CWE-327
CWE-327.description: The use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm is an unnecessary risk that may result in the exposure of sensitive information.

FF1049.name: FF1049
FF1049.description: The crypt functions use a poor one-way hashing algorithm; since they only accept passwords of 8 characters or fewer and only a two-byte salt, they are excessively vulnerable to dictionary attacks given today's faster computing equipment

FF1048.name: FF1048
FF1048.description: This function is not sufficiently random for security-related functions such as key and nonce creation

FF1050.name: FF1050
FF1050.description: DES only supports a 56-bit keysize, which is too small given today's computers

FF1051.name: FF1051
FF1051.description: These keysizes are too small given today's computers

Cross_cutting.name: Cross_cutting
Cross_cutting.description: Weaknesses in this category are related to the design and architecture of multiple security tactics and how they affect a system. A weakness in this category could lead to a degradation in the quality of many capabilities.

CWE-807 Reliance_on_untrusted_inputs.name: CWE-807 Reliance_on_untrusted_inputs
CWE-807 Reliance_on_untrusted_inputs.description: The application uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of an input, but the input can be modified by an untrusted actor in a way that bypasses the protection mechanism.

FF1053.name: FF1053
FF1053.description: Environment variables are untrustable input if they can be set by an attacker.  They can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

FF1054.name: FF1054
FF1054.description: This function is synonymous with 'getenv(\"HOME\")';it returns untrustable input if the environment can be set by an attacker.  It can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

FF1055.name: FF1055
FF1055.description: This function is synonymous with 'getenv(\"TMP\")';it returns untrustable input if the environment can be set by an attacker. It can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

CWE-807.name: CWE-807
CWE-807.description: The application uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of an input, but the input can be modified by an untrusted actor in a way that bypasses the protection mechanism.

FF1062.name: FF1062
FF1062.description: It's often easy to fool getlogin.  Sometimes it does not work at all, because some program messed up the utmp file.  Often, it gives only the first 8 characters of the login name. The user currently logged in on the controlling tty of our program need not be the user who started it.  Avoid getlogin() for security-related purposes

Limit_exposure.name: Limit_exposure
Limit_exposure.description: Weaknesses in this category are related to the design and architecture of the entry points to a system. Frequently these deal with minimizing the attack surface through designing the system with the least needed amount of entry points.

CWE-829 Inclusion_of_functionality_from_.name: CWE-829 Inclusion_of_functionality_from_untrusted_control_sphere
CWE-829 Inclusion_of_functionality_from_.description: The software imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

FF1058.name: FF1058
FF1058.description: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used

FF1059.name: FF1059
FF1059.description: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used

Integrity.name: Integrity
Integrity.description: Guarding against improper information modification or destruction, and includes ensuring information non-repudiation and authenticity.

CWE-190 Integer_wraparound.name: CWE-190 Integer_wraparound
CWE-190 Integer_wraparound.description: The software performs a calculation that can produce an integer overflow or wraparound, when the logic assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than the original value. This can introduce other weaknesses when the calculation is used for resource management or execution control.

CWE-190.name: CWE-190
CWE-190.description: The software performs a calculation that can produce an integer overflow or wraparound, when the logic assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than the original value. This can introduce other weaknesses when the calculation is used for resource management or execution control.

FF1047.name: FF1047
FF1047.description: Unless checked, the resulting number can exceed the expected range

CWE-77 OS_command_injection.name: CWE-77 OS_command_injection
CWE-77 OS_command_injection.description: The software constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.

CWE-78.name: CWE-78
CWE-78.description: The software constructs all or part of an OS command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended OS command when it is sent to a downstream component.

FF1045.name: FF1045
FF1045.description: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1046.name: FF1046
FF1046.description: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1043.name: FF1043
FF1043.description: This causes a new program to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1044.name: FF1044
FF1044.description: This causes a new program to execute and is difficult to use safely

CWE-119 Improper_restriction_of_operatio.name: CWE-119 Improper_restriction_of_operations_in_memory
CWE-119 Improper_restriction_of_operatio.description: The software performs operations on a memory buffer, but it can read from or write to a memory location that is outside of the intended boundary of the buffer.

CWE-126.name: CWE-126
CWE-126.description: The software reads from a buffer using buffer access mechanisms such as indexes or pointers that reference memory locations after the targeted buffer.

FF1022.name: FF1022
FF1022.description: Does not handle strings that are not \\0-terminated; if given one it may perform an over-read (it could cause a crash if unprotected)

FF1071.name: FF1071
FF1071.description: Function does not check the second iterator for over-read conditions

FF1065.name: FF1065
FF1065.description: This function is obsolete and not portable. It was in SUSv2 but removed by POSIX.2.  What it does exactly varies considerably between systems, particularly in where its prompt is displayed and where it gets its data (e.g., /dev/tty, stdin, stderr, etc.). In addition, some implementations overflow buffers.

FF1027.name: FF1027
FF1027.description: Some older implementations do not protect against internal buffer overflows

FF1028.name: FF1028
FF1028.description: This does not protect against buffer overflows by itself, so use with caution

FF1029.name: FF1029
FF1029.description: Check buffer boundaries if used in a loop including recursive loops

FF1014.name: FF1014
FF1014.description: Does not check for buffer overflows

FF1020.name: FF1020
FF1020.description: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows

FF1021.name: FF1021
FF1021.description: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows

FF1013.name: FF1013
FF1013.description: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues

CWE-120.name: CWE-120
CWE-120.description: The program copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer, leading to a buffer overflow.

In addition, some implementations overflow buffers.

CWE-190.name: CWE-190
CWE-190.description: The software performs a calculation that can produce an integer overflow or wraparound, when the logic assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than the original value. This can introduce other weaknesses when the calculation is used for resource management or execution control.

FF1047.name: FF1047
FF1047.description: Unless checked, the resulting number can exceed the expected range

FF1013.name: FF1013
FF1013.description: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues

CWE-807.name: CWE-807
CWE-807.description: The application uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of an input, but the input can be modified by an untrusted actor in a way that bypasses the protection mechanism.

FF1062.name: FF1062
FF1062.description: It's often easy to fool getlogin.  Sometimes it does not work at all, because some program messed up the utmp file.  Often, it gives only the first 8 characters of the login name. The user currently logged in on the controlling tty of our program need not be the user who started it.  Avoid getlogin() for security-related purposes

FF1035.name: FF1035
FF1035.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results. Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL.

FF1058.name: FF1058
FF1058.description: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used

FF1059.name: FF1059
FF1059.description: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used

FF1027.name: FF1027
FF1027.description: Some older implementations do not protect against internal buffer overflows

FF1028.name: FF1028
FF1028.description: This does not protect against buffer overflows by itself, so use with caution

FF1029.name: FF1029
FF1029.description: Check buffer boundaries if used in a loop including recursive loops

FF1023.name: FF1023
FF1023.description: Requires maximum length in CHARACTERS, not bytes

FF1024.name: FF1024
FF1024.description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows

FF1069.name: FF1069
FF1069.description: This C routine is considered obsolete (as opposed to the shell command by the same name).   The interaction of this function with SIGALRM and other timer functions such as sleep(), alarm(), setitimer(), and nanosleep() is unspecified

FF1025.name: FF1025
FF1025.description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows

FF1026.name: FF1026
FF1026.description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows, and some implementations can overflow internally

FF1030.name: FF1030
FF1030.description: This usually indicates a security flaw.  If an attacker can change anything along the path between the call to access() and the file's actual use (e.g., by moving files), the attacker can exploit the race condition

FF1031.name: FF1031
FF1031.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1032.name: FF1032
FF1032.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1033.name: FF1033
FF1033.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results.

FF1071.name: FF1071
FF1071.description: Function does not check the second iterator for over-read conditions

FF1016.name: FF1016
FF1016.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1017.name: FF1017
FF1017.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1018.name: FF1018
FF1018.description: If syslog's format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited

FF1019.name: FF1019
FF1019.description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited, and note that sprintf variations do not always 0-terminate

FF1056.name: FF1056
FF1056.description: If this call fails, the program could fail to drop heightened privileges

FF1012.name: FF1012
FF1012.description: Subject to buffer overflow if buffer is not as big as claimed

FF1013.name: FF1013
FF1013.description: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues

FF1058.name: FF1058
FF1058.description: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used

FF1014.name: FF1014
FF1014.description: Does not check for buffer overflows

FF1059.name: FF1059
FF1059.description: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used

FF1020.name: FF1020
FF1020.description: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows

FF1064.name: FF1064
FF1064.description: This function is dangerous; it may overflow the provided buffer. It extracts data from a 'protected' area, but most systems have many commands to let users modify the protected area, and it's not always clear what their limits are.  Best to avoid using this function altogether

FF1065.name: FF1065
FF1065.description: This function is obsolete and not portable. It was in SUSv2 but removed by POSIX.2.  What it does exactly varies considerably between systems, particularly in where its prompt is displayed and where it gets its data (e.g., /dev/tty, stdin, stderr, etc.). In addition, some implementations overflow buffers.

FF1021.name: FF1021
FF1021.description: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows

FF1066.name: FF1066
FF1066.description: These functions are considered obsolete on most systems, and very non-portable (Linux-based systems handle them radically different, basically if gsignal/ssignal were the same as raise/signal respectively, while System V considers them a separate set and obsolete)

FF1022.name: FF1022
FF1022.description: Does not handle strings that are not \\0-terminated; if given one it may perform an over-read (it could cause a crash if unprotected)

FF1060.name: FF1060
FF1060.description: Never create NULL ACLs; an attacker can set it to Everyone (Deny All Access), which would even forbid administrator access

FF1061.name: FF1061
FF1061.description: This doesn't set the inheritance bits in the access control entry (ACE) header

FF1062.name: FF1062
FF1062.description: It's often easy to fool getlogin.  Sometimes it does not work at all, because some program messed up the utmp file.  Often, it gives only the first 8 characters of the login name. The user currently logged in on the controlling tty of our program need not be the user who started it.  Avoid getlogin() for security-related purposes

FF1049.name: FF1049
FF1049.description: The crypt functions use a poor one-way hashing algorithm; since they only accept passwords of 8 characters or fewer and only a two-byte salt, they are excessively vulnerable to dictionary attacks given today's faster computing equipment

FF1005.name: FF1005
FF1005.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when concatenating to destination [MS-banned]

FF1006.name: FF1006
FF1006.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when concatenating to destination [MS-banned]

FF1007.name: FF1007
FF1007.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when concatenating to destination [MS-banned]

FF1008.name: FF1008
FF1008.description: Easily used incorrectly; doesn't always \\0-terminate or check for invalid pointers [MS-banned]

FF1045.name: FF1045
FF1045.description: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1001.name: FF1001
FF1001.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned]

FF1046.name: FF1046
FF1046.description: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1002.name: FF1002
FF1002.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned]

FF1047.name: FF1047
FF1047.description: Unless checked, the resulting number can exceed the expected range

FF1003.name: FF1003
FF1003.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned]

FF1048.name: FF1048
FF1048.description: This function is not sufficiently random for security-related functions such as key and nonce creation

FF1004.name: FF1004
FF1004.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination

FF1009.name: FF1009
FF1009.description: Easily used incorrectly; doesn't always \\0-terminate or check for invalid pointers [MS-banned]

FF1052.name: FF1052
FF1052.description: chroot can be very helpful, but is hard to use correctly

FF1053.name: FF1053
FF1053.description: Environment variables are untrustable input if they can be set by an attacker.  They can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

FF1054.name: FF1054
FF1054.description: This function is synonymous with 'getenv(\"HOME\")';it returns untrustable input if the environment can be set by an attacker.  It can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

FF1010.name: FF1010
FF1010.description: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned]

FF1055.name: FF1055
FF1055.description: This function is synonymous with 'getenv(\"TMP\")';it returns untrustable input if the environment can be set by an attacker. It can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once

FF1011.name: FF1011
FF1011.description: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned]

FF1050.name: FF1050
FF1050.description: DES only supports a 56-bit keysize, which is too small given today's computers

FF1051.name: FF1051
FF1051.description: These keysizes are too small given today's computers

FF1039.name: FF1039
FF1039.description: Potential for temporary file vulnerability in some circumstances.  Some older Unix-like systems create temp files with permission to write by all by default, so be sure to set the umask to override this. Also, some older Unix systems might fail to use O_EXCL when opening the file, so make sure that O_EXCL is used by the library

FF1034.name: FF1034
FF1034.description: On some old systems, vfork() permits race conditions, and it's very difficult to use correctly

FF1035.name: FF1035
FF1035.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results. Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL.

FF1036.name: FF1036
FF1036.description: Function tmpfile() has a security flaw on some systems (e.g., older System V systems)

FF1041.name: FF1041
FF1041.description: Ensure that umask is given most restrictive possible setting (e.g., 066 or 077)

FF1042.name: FF1042
FF1042.description: Temporary file race condition in certain cases (e.g., if run as SYSTEM in many versions of Windows)

FF1043.name: FF1043
FF1043.description: This causes a new program to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1044.name: FF1044
FF1044.description: This causes a new program to execute and is difficult to use safely

FF1040.name: FF1040
FF1040.description: Check when opening files - can an attacker redirect it (via symlinks), force the opening of special file type (e.g., device files), move things around to create a race condition, control its ancestors, or change its contents?
